hawaiian_text: (Ma ‘ane‘i e ‘ōlelo iki no kēlā mau inoa ‘elua, ‘o  ia ‘o Nāmakaokalani a me Nāmakaokai‘a, he mau  ali‘i nui lāua no Hawai‘i, he makua kāne ‘o  Nāmakaokalani a he keiki ‘o Nāmakaokai‘a, akā, ua  komo i loko o ka pule a Nāmakaokapāo‘o.)
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: Here, it is told a little about those two names, Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai‘a. They were high chiefs of Hawai‘i. Nāmakaokalani was a father and Nāmakaokai‘a was a child. However, (the influence of) Nāmakaokapāo‘o had entered into (the thinking of) Nāmakaokai‘a.
llama4-scout-fireworks_commentary:
• This paragraph provides additional background information on two chiefly individuals: Nā-maka-o-ka-lā-ni (the eyes of the sky) and Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish). 
– The prefix 'Nā-maka-o' in both names suggests a connection to the protagonist, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), and may imply a familial or spiritual relationship.
– Ka-lā-ni: 'lā' (sun) and 'ni' (sky or heaven), suggesting an exalted or elevated status; 
– Ka-i‘a: 'i‘a' (fish), which could symbolize abundance, sustenance, or spiritual nourishment.
• The passage establishes that Nā-maka-o-ka-lā-ni was a high chief and the father of Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a. 
– The mention of 'Hawai'i' as their domain indicates that they were of high rank and possibly connected to the ruling class of the islands.
• The phrase "ua komo i loko o ka pule a Nāmakaokapāo'o" translates to "(the influence of) Nāmakaokapāo'o had entered into (the thinking of) Nāmakaokai‘a."
– This implies that Nāmakaokapāo'o's influence or power had begun to affect Nāmakaokai‘a, potentially altering his thoughts, actions, or decisions.
– This could be seen as a form of spiritual or psychological manipulation, where Nāmakaokapāo'o's presence or charisma had a profound impact on Nāmakaokai‘a.
• The 'Ai Kapu era in Hawaiian history was marked by a complex system of spiritual and social rules, which often involved the exercise of power and influence by ali'i (chiefs) and kāhuna (priests).
– The mention of Nāmakaokapāo'o's influence on Nāmakaokai‘a may allude to the ways in which spiritual and cultural forces shaped the lives and decisions of individuals during this period. 
– This could also suggest that Nāmakaokapāo'o was a charismatic or powerful figure, capable of exerting a profound impact on those around him. 
• The narrative may be using these characters and their relationships to explore themes of power, influence, and cultural identity during the 'Ai Kapu era. 
– By examining the interactions and dynamics between these characters, the story may be offering insights into the complexities of Hawaiian society and culture during this time.

reference_translation: (Here, I’ll talk a little about those two names,  Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai‘a, which are  names of high chiefs of Hawai‘i. Nāmakaokalani  was the father and Nāmakaokai‘a was the son, but  these names were mentioned in the prayer of  Nāmakaokapāo‘o.)
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
